remixed_from.author: jonaskuehling
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears, Parametric Filament

description.text: This is a modification to jonaskuehling's version of the famous Gregs Wade Extruder. I am participating in a 18 unit Prusa group build (using TOMs primarily to print the parts!) We wanted this version, but need both 3 mm and 1.75 versions. I noted as others that the filament path wasn't completly parameterized and that the guidler moves in Z. I believe I have solved the issue, you can read my comments, any code changed by me has a //DEC comment. I have printed a 1.75 mm version, and it seems correct. I also mover the guidler so that the three parts (body, washer and guidler) fits on a 100mm square build platform

No new instructions, just fixed the SCAD code. The filament hole may be a bit tight, I reamed mine out with a 2mm (#46) drill. 
Version 2 - Some more improvements. I designed a clasp that rides along the 4mm bolts, and allows a 3mm screw to drop into a hole in the guidler, no more slipping off. I also added a throat to the entry of the filament path, below the idler-bolt junction. Hopefully we can feed filament into the guidler with it closed and it won't jam. I also rounded the edge that the m3 screw has to pass over to make it easier to use. The stls have been run through NetFabb's cleanup service. The springs that I use are seat springs for Delta/Peerless faucets.

comments.text: I cani use it in 3 mm bowden configuration?
comments.author: Edsol

comments.text: Combining a few different designs for a custom one of my own. A few quick questions, if I may.
comments.author: daichiasuka

comments.text: Yes, the bolts tended to slip out on the original design. The M3 screw is held in place by an M3 nut in the plate, there should be a hexagon shaped recess for it. The knob was intended to make it easier to pull the M3 screw, but it is a clumsy design and I don't use it. It isn't even in the photo that I posted.
comments.author: daichiasuka

comments.text: Ohh, I see. The M3 screw attaches to the plate so it doesn't fall out, but the length of the screw works like a lever into the idler to stop the spring tension from working the idler screws up and out of the slots.
comments.author: dougc314

comments.text: The M3 screw works more like a pull knob than a lever. The idea is to pull on the M3 screw, compressing the springs, then with the idler arm all the way up, pressing the bearing against the hobbed bolt the spring-plate assembly can be moved down over the bearing arm and released. The screw end of the  of the M3 bolt sticks out of the plate and catches a depression in the bearing arm. They lock together well. I have been using this design constantly since posting, and many of my friends have. Of course most if the design isn't mine, I just modified it in a few ways that I felt were improvements. I almost never have to dis-engage the plate. I can change filament with the idler arm in place, thanks to the funnel shape throat in the filament path. I am printing out something right now on the machine that I built that used this extruder. I think I'm on the second body, I had an extruder "accident" that melted the first one.
comments.author: daichiasuka

comments.text: I see. Thanks. I think I'm going to add something like this to my final design.
comments.author: dougc314

comments.author: TECHGEEK

comments.text: Im trying to print nylon with my wade extruder but find it to be too flexible. If even a little too much pressure builds up it just bends right after the hobbed bolt, before getting guided into the through hole. Do you think your funneled V2 version would be better or worse for printing more flexible filament? Have you ever had any success printing nylon with a wade?
comments.author: archy587

comments.text: Probably worse, as it would let the filament bend more. I think the extruders that support the higher compression forces  have a carefully designed filament path that extends very close to the pinch point of the filament.
comments.author: archy587

comments.text: dougc314,
comments.author: Jammer

comments.text: I just checked in a couple of ways. I checked the code and they are 13.7 mm (C-C) apart for the J-head. I also checked a printed one, and verified that. The way the mount works is that the inner surface of the screws, (they're about 10.7 mm apart grab the 12 mm j-head circular slot tightly. I've used this with both maker gear and EBAY-China jheads and it works well. I suppose an aluminum j-head may be a bit hard. Just to be clear, the screw threads bite into the 12 mm circular slot, holding the jhead very snugly.
comments.author: Jammer

comments.text: dougc314,
comments.author: dougc314

comments.text: Very nice.
comments.author: infodude

comments.text: Â Sorry about the "not manifold" issue. There seems to be a difference about the slicing engines and how fussy and or accurate they are about this issue. Skeinforge processes the stls and prints them, SLIC3r doesn't. I have no idea how to fix it in the source code. When slic3r complains about an STL I use NetFABB cloud service (or the stand alone netfabb program) to repair them. At the time of posting I wasn't using slic3r so had no idea that it was unhappy.
comments.author: infodude

comments.text: I tried to compile and save the scad file attached.
comments.author: Jtisdo

comments.text: I suppose I might have changed something in the dependent scad's and forgotten. I just uploaded a zip of all the SCAD files required to build the extruder. I copied them to a new folder and compiled the design and generated a stl. Seems to work. There are libraries that come with OpenSCAD that may be required as well.
comments.author: Jtisdo

comments.text: I am using OpenSCAD 2011.12.30 and Python27. Obviously it generates STL files for me. Which SCAD file? You should be using V2, but both should work. I have had another person have problems with the SCAD file, thinking it was corrupted. I have downloaded it from thingiverse several times, the downloaded file is identical. Email me and I will send you the file direct. In fact please email me your downloaded copy so I can compare them.
comments.author: Jtisdo

comments.text: I am using the same  - it might be be because the you haven't posted all the scad files . you might have modified something in them that change the dimensions -- that kind of thing will mess up the manifold.
comments.author: dougc314

comments.text: where does the plastic washer go? Do we just need the two gears from the original version? Thanks for the model!
comments.author: drkow

comments.text: Use the gears from 18379 , the thing this is derived from. The washer goes in the bearing well on the gear side, under the bearing, it stops the center boss of the bearing from binding on the extruder body.
comments.author: drkow

description.text: I found that nozzles come with nice numbers on the side that indicate the size of the opening. This is great. As long as you don't use them, you'll always be able to tell what they are. To avoid confusion on which is which I made this rack that shows the size. As long as I put the nozzle where it's supposed to be I should be able to tell the difference. The holes for the nozzle are a tad tight, but they do allow for the nozzles to be screwwed in place. Keeps them there if I accidently knock the rack to the floor. The openings on the top are meant to hold thos drill thingies you can get for cleaning blackages. Since I don't own any I had to guess the size. They're about 6mm in diameter. If you do have a drill set you may have to ream the holes to suit. I use the little "shelf" for storing hex keys. Not gorgeous by any means but it works for me. Created in 3D Builder

I make no claim to the suitability or airworthiness of this part. Use of this part is at your own risk.

Holes for rheostat shaft and set screw are pilot holes only and need to be brought up or tapped to final size.

This air frame is great for learning to fly on. It has a low center of mass which give it a lot of stability and it is tough enough to take some hard crashes.

I designed it to use:

10mm Carbon Fiber Tubes
Naze32 10DOF
Minim OSD
DX2205 2300KV Motors
PZ0420 Camera
TS351 VTX
HC-SR04 Sonar Module
5v 3amp UBEC
Makerfire 4pcs ESC 20A
Polarized Clover Leaf Antenna
2200 mAh battery

Printer:

AM

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print in ABS. There are a couple of things that you will need to glue together, I recommend using pvc pipe glue and don't forget to also use the primer.
The holes in the parts for fasteners are just for place holders. You will need to go back over the parts with the proper size drill bit to match the size of the screws that you are using. For best results, have a range of drill bits and step up the hole's size to avoid splitting you part.
There are two different front nose sections, one for use with a sonar module and one for without. I highly recommend using the sonar, it makes flying fpv so much fun, kind of like starwars pod racing. Once you have your sonar PIDs tuned right, you'll know what I mean.
Depending on what size battery you use, you might need to slide the motor spars forward to rear to align the center of thrust to the center of mass.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/SAGxVQoYh0M" ></iframe>

print_settings.Notes:: The motor coupler was printed lying down to give the best strength when the motor is driving, though the torque here is very low.

description.text:
There are three part designs here. Each might be useful on its own.
Motor Bracket
Motor Coupler
Pillow Blocks

The Motor Bracket is my first 3d design (yay me!). It requires some minor sanding to get things to fit. Need to learn to not call things so tight.

There is a coupler for a stepper motor to a 5/16 threaded rod. The rod end needs to be tapped since it has no threads (my modeling skills are up to making threads yet). This is destined for my telescope mount.

The pillow blocks hold skate board bearings. The fit for the bearings is a little lose but the nuts hold everything in place so all is good ;-).

Printer:

JG Aurora A3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The motor coupler was printed lying down to give the best strength when the motor is driving, though the torque here is very low.

The tricky bit is the friction fit on the stepper motor shaft. Learned to use an octagonal profile to allow the shaft to fit without requiring exact tolerances. Anyway, even simple objects teach you things when you are starting.

comments.text: The worm drive looks great.  Did you ever design/print/make/buy the worm gear that fits the telescope and this Thing?  I would be most interested to find a source for the other half of your project.

comments.text: I had made the gear before I got a printer by hobbing some MDF using a drill and tap. I was going to go back and make a 3d model for the gear but haven't gotten back to it.

author: the5h33f1

description.text:
Embossed star coins from Super Mario 64 have many uses!
  • Print out a bunch of yellow ones and use circles of them to mark the warp zones and other secrets in your house!
  • Print out 8 red ones and place them in a platformy area of your house and award a star to anyone who finds all of them!
  • Print out some blue ones because blue coins are cool!

• Printing 100 of them will not grant you an extra life.
  • Coins cannot be used as an underwater breathing apparatus.
  • Coins will not heal any injury.
  • Coins are legal tender only in the Mushroom Kingdom, and may not be used for any debts outside of the Mushroom Kingdom, including, but not limited to, cake purchases, yellow rabbit traps, or stolen hat insurance.

É uma luminária para ser acoplada em máquinas fotográficas profissionais, para iluminar o ambiente para a gravação de vídeos.
Como máquinas fotográficas profissionais não possuem luz para iluminar o ambiente de gravação, com essa luminária é possível clarear o local de filmagem. Luminárias prontas nesse estilo, comercialmente falando, possuem um preço muito elevado (mais de R$ 700,00), e com esse projeto o custo não chega a R$ 50,00.
A impressão da caixa para acoplar todo o circuito eletrônico é impresso em impressora 3D e a montagem do circuito eletrônico bem como a alocação dele na caixa é elaborada por mim.

author: Mustang7302

description.text: NOTE THIS IS NOT A DROP IN PIECE* Stryfe Rev Trigger. Used for the rev switch on a Stryfe. This requires sanding to smooth out any defects. The trigger is designed to be used with a microswitch, not the stock switch (although this can be possible with some grinding on a rotary tool, which is why I made this intentionally big). I have used this in a Stryfe build, and I can verify that it does work with some sanding and lubrication (as expected). Please feel free to make any design changes, and if you do, be sure to credit me.

comments.text: This required a lot more hand-finishing than I expected.  I also had to dremel out some pieces of the shell in my Stryfe to get it to fit.  I also glued what used to be the rev-trigger lock in place, which I had previously removed, since it appears to be used as the guide for this design.  In the end, I got it working, but don't expect a plug-and-play.  I expected to spend some time installing the aftermarket microswitch, but I thought the trigger would be a more popular 3D printed part and could be dropped in.
comments.author: Propter_Hoc

comments.text: Thank you for your feedback. I will be working on a drop in replacement for the stock trigger, although it is a rather complex design.
comments.author: Propter_Hoc

comments.text: With some sanding and lubrication, this works!

title: Monoprice Select Mini ABS and PLA air duct

description.text:
-=UPDATE=-
I have moved on to other projects so I have updated the last version I created as well as the .123d design file to make it easier to modify for whoever wants to.
There are still a few issues such as the PLA vent being about 1cm too long, and the tolerances are a bit tight.

An air duct for the Monoprice Mini that clips on and has two bottom plates that slide into place. One is a block off plate for use with ABS and the other is a vent duct for use with PLA.
This is currently a WIP

-=UPDATE=-
There are a few very minor issues with the design.

1) After printing, the bottom plates are a bit snug of a fit. These can be sanded down to make them fit easier. I am redesigning them to have looser tolerances.
2) The mounting points are 4mm too low. This is not a major issue, however the duct does not cover the heat sink properly. These will be moved up in the next revision
3) The tabs to snap onto the carriage are a hair too thick. Again, they can be shaved down after printing to make them fit. These will be thinned down in the next revision.

comments.text: Let us know when you get the changes made, looks interesting!

author: icefox1983

description.text: i made the holes wider for a 8-32 rod

This is a case designed for the Amazon Fire 7" Tablet. This case was designed around this particular tablet, and probably will not be compatible with any other tablets. The Fire 7" tablet is a very inexpensive tablet. Normally selling for about $50, you can sometimes pick one up for as low as $30 on sale. As such, it makes for a wonderful in-car entertainment device for your kids. I wanted to create a versatile case for my kids tablets. This case comes in 3 parts for easy printing. (Left, Middle, and Right sections). The middle section is optional, and can be used with only the left and right sections.

Some of the features of the case include:

  • Grips on the sides to give a nice comfortable hold when watching moves or playing games in landscape mode.
  • Grips also act as a kick stand to allow the tablet to stand up on a flat surface.
  • Mounts to back of a car headrest for easy in-car entertainment
  • Optional caring handle for to help little ones from dropping

About the mounting brackets for adjustable headrests: These brackets are designed for the 2-post, adjustable headrests. To use the headrest mounts, you simply pull up your headrest and slip on the headrest brackets. Then snap on the swivel clips on the end of each bracket. Then these clips push into the slots on either side of the grips on the tablet case. I've included two types of brackets, a solid one to use if you can completely remove your headrest, and a split one you can snap around the headrest posts if it's not removable.
The brackets are universal, but the swivel clips are specific for Left vs Right.

There's also an optional carrying handle This handle snaps into the same slots as the head rest mounts, and can be easily removed when not needed. I've included the full handle, as well as a split version which should be glued together once printed. The split version is for smaller prints which cannot accommodate the full handle. (The split on as a peg which slides into a slot on it's mate. This peg will probably need support when printing.)

Reach3D

Supports:

No

25%

title: Galaxy S7 Edge drop-in car dock (rev 2.0)

description.text:
This is revision 2 of a drop in dock design. Revision 1 is functional, but requires a number of improvements.

Changes.

  1. Cleanup internal geometry, unnecessary faces and edges
  2. widen rear support of device by 1mm, to make it a bit easier to insert/remove phone.
  3. angle and taper curved sides to make phone easier to insert, and minimize material.
  4. moved base up about 3mm relative to diamond mounts.
  5. reduce the front wall support to be 3mm across entire device.

If you are adapting this design, I recommend measuring and adjusting the position of the USB hole for a perfect friction fit and to make sure it lines up with the port on the phone.

The width of the Caseology case is about 78mm, and the dock internal width is about 79.5mm.

Youtube review of the functional 3D print in my Chevy Volt.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fB2ULfGEWvA

Note: I tested this dock with a Nexus 5x with a TPU case on it, and it fit rather well, but I need to adjust the USB port size a bit.

print_settings.Notes:: DO NOT put in dishwasher since the plastic is likely to deform from the heat. Only clean with warm water and dish soap.

description.text:
The outer edge cuts, and the inner details leaves an imprint in the dough.

Dimensions

  • Height: 10 mm
  • Imprint height: 7 mm

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use PLA since it's rated as food safe, plus it won't warp.

The cutters varies in size but I've found that min. 14-15 cm in Y direction gives a good result. At that size the internal details prints nicely.
Scale them in your slicer.

The outer walls and bottom are 1,5 mm thick to give the cutter some rigidity.When slicing the model, scale z independently so that the mold becomes 10 mm high. This is to maintain the proper cutting depth and bottomplate thickness

DO NOT put in dishwasher since the plastic is likely to deform from the heat. Only clean with warm water and dish soap.

Edge cleanup

There could be some minor stringing between walls. Cut/ peel off with a small sharp knife.

To create these, I used coloring book motifs that I converted into vector format. For this I used the free software Incscape but any vector graphics program works fine.
Google "character name coloring pages" to find suitable pictures to work with.

  1. Save the picture you want and import it into Incscape.
  2. In incscape, create a bitmap copy of the object.
  3. Trace the lines of the bitmap. Use threshold 0,0 to get thicker lines. Simpler pictures works best, you don't want crazy amouts of detail since the 3D printer most likely will not be able to print it properly anyway. Some cleanup of the picture might be required to get it right for 3D printing. Make sure the outer edge is solid.
  4. Save as DXF or SVG format. This might depend on wich CAD-program you're using.
  5. Open the file in your CAD-program. Add the picture to a sketch and create your cookie cutter. Experiment to find what's working best for your setup.

title: Lulzbot Mini Toolholder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by jiaqiren's toolholder for the Lulzbot Mini, I designed an own version of it. Despite I like the idea of the design I wanted a more custom version of it which fit perfectly to the tools delivered with the printer.

The toolholder sits on the left side of the printer, above the power supply. In this way the toolholder won't block the view on my print and fits in nicely.
Every tool delivered with the Lulzbot Mini and additionally a standard sized 30mm glue stick has his own tailored compartment. The tools can be stowed and withdrawn easily.

After working with the toolholder for quite a while I am very pleased with the design and the practical benefit of the part.
If you have questions or additional ideas just let me know!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

0.2

Notes:

I printed the toolholder for presentation purposes in white nGen, but black will fit to the design of the printer perfectly.
The print takes 9:14h and 96gram of filament.

I printed the design without any supports or rafts.
The big bridging area of the gluestick holder could use some kind of support, but this would take an eternity longer and would only have a small effect since no one look inside the holder. With a shell size of 1mm the outer shell will be smooth.

author: Puzzles

description.text:
This small piece comes inbetween your extruder and the hotend and guides the filament properly into the hotend tube. It can help prevent the notorious clicking issue, which is caused by the big gap between the two parts. The filament tends to miss the entry of the hontend and is then stuck onto the edge of the tube.

It also helps printing soft materials like TPE, which where unprintable for me since the material I used, tends to go inbetween the hotend and the extruder, due to the materials softness.
It still happens if you print/extrude to fast, but atleast I can print TPE.

Printing & Installation

Disclaimer: I take no responsabilities for damaged printers or injuries! Try this at your own risk.

I printed my guide out of PETG, since I didn't know how hot the tube of hotend can get. The filament I use can withstand up to 90°C and after several prints(up to 240°C) it still doesn't show any melting.

You might have to sand the piece a bit after printing it, to clear any strings and I also had to clean the hole. Use a 5mm drill bit for the first 2.5mm starting from the bottom and then a 3mm drill bit to go through the hole.

To install the the guide, you have to disassemble the print head, until you're left with the extruder and the hotend like in the picture above.

Below the extruder are two threads with the grub screws, which hold the hotend in place. Unscrew them until the hotend comes loose and pull it out a bit, so that you can insert the filament guide. Now push the hotend back in so that the tube of the hotend gets into the guide. Screw the grub screws back in to fixate the hotend, but be very carefull to not to overtighten them, since you can damage the aluminum threads very easily.

Now put the print head back together and enjoy inserting your filament on the first try (took me every time several minutes without the filament guide)!

Fusion 360 file

Some one asked for the plans so here is the link to the Fusion 360 file. Please post your remixes, if you make modifications based on the file!
http://a360.co/2q0TopF

Kodama Trinus

title: Samsung SWA-8000S Rear Speaker Wall Mount

description.text:
I purchased a Samsung Soundbar with the SWA-8000S Rear Speakers. Due to how my couch was positioned, adding stands was not an option. I realized I would need to wall mount the rear speakers, but if I mounted them flush they would almost be facing away from the couch. I decided to design the mount above to mount them at 30 degrees facing inward toward the couch to get me that deep surround sound feel I was looking for.

The file you are downloading is for a right speaker mount. To print the left I just mirrored around the X-Axis in Slic3r.

title: Sculptr Delta Extruder arm Endpieces for M3/M4 threaded rod

description.text:
I cut off the middle part off the 150mm Arms and made a m4 hole in the middle.
I use it with a M4 threaded rod so I drilled it out a bit (at first I thought I had m3)
It gives a lot more stiffness to the extruder arms and as an additional bonus you can adjust the hole to hole distance really precise with the threaded rods.

(corrected the mistake I made in naming it it's actually for m3 and ,m4 (stupid me for saying m5 you will destroy it) if you use if for m4 drill it out a bit )

author: FreeFlight

description.text: Little ninja with modular weapons.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g81Owu2dPn7

I present to you the Spinning Desktop Bee Hive! Fun, bright, and easy to print... who doesn't need a swarm of bees?! If you have a fan or an open window, the hive will spin in the breeze or you can give it a spin yourself. All you need is some yellow filament, a black marker, a standard push pin, and three paperclips. Assembly is kind of self explanatory but I cut the paper clips to different lengths (making sure two of each length for balance) and heated them up before inserting them so that they melt the plastic a little for a tight bond. Hope you enjoy it! I had fun designing it, one of my first original designs!

author: Mayolli

description.text: Ferrari USB holder, or can be made into a USB Hub.

Some time ago on internets I came across wooden sculptures made in late 80's by Mexican artist Guillermo Kuhn Sanchez that he called dual art.
Inspired by his work I decided to do something similar, and here you go: Deergle!

I designed Deergle so it can be printed without supports, although there are some steep(ish) overhangs that can droop a little, depending of your setup. You can see those blops and droops on my example photos, but I think those would be easy to clean up, at least if you are not as lazy as I am.

With no scaling the STL will give you about 90mm tall Deergle, that's the size I printed it. I haven't printed it in bigger size, but I think it might give better result.

Have fun!

title: colloidal silver heated magnetic spinner lab stirrer

description.text:
Colloidal silver heated magnetic spinner

you need to print this in abs because of heat bed. print at 100% infill or it will tear itself apart warping i put felt pads on the bottom in the four corners

Spinner
40mm cpu fan 12v
10x2mm magnets x2
M3x60 and aquarium tubing for spacer

heat bed ( http://dirtypcbs.com/store/designer/details/peter.plaaswerf%40gmail.com/168/100x100mm-3d-printer-heated-bed )
a proto pack is 12 of them if i remember right
the heat bed helps speed up Electroless in the distilled water

555 pwm x3 ( scamatic is in pics )
allows you to control temp and spinner speed also pulse on electrodes helps control particle size

There are some holes that need drilled IE to hold top on to mount fan inside and for heal bed
for 12v power supply i used xbox 360 power brick

You will need to modify the 555 pwm schematic for this project but if you cant see what needs changed you probably cant build the timer yourself anyway LOL.. It is the same timer you would use in a PWM box mod

the glass came from the Dollar tree and the coated magnetic spinner came from ebay
silver rods came from ebay only use 9999 silver

author: Ghostface

description.text:
That is the so-called "Laboratory" Power Supply Unit. Needed to power and measure all that devices to be used in DIY projects. For a long time I did use the laptop power supply with a voltage switch (after equiped it with one of that $1 3-dgit voltmeters) + StepDown. Very nice and unexpensive setup, should I say. But not so nice when you own the 3D Printer. Finally I was ready to spend another 2 days on new project and now happy to present results to you.

The PSU features regulated output voltage 0...23.5V, current limit setup upto 3A, small form-factor... Ok, you need the following to make one yourself (most of the parts should be modified that or another way but nothing too hard):

1) 24V 6A PSU available from a lot of sources. Found the cheap PSUs source here: EDT-100W AC-DC Converter 110V 220V to 24V DC 6A Power Supply Switching Transformer - we are going to load no more than 24Vx3A(/eff,~90%) - no more than 75W in well-ventilated device, hope that is OK. The price is less than $5! And I did not find any problems with components that PSU is made of.
2) StepDown module with all that settings and limits, B3603. Mine was bought years ago from Banggood for the same $12.10 as the sell now (bought 3 pcs). Sure you can find it cheaper. It is based on LM2596 so 3A current is the limit (well-ventilated, again).
3) mini360 step-down like that one from Banggood (to be honest, that are 5, not one, but at $0.70 each) - used it to power the 12V air fan (not going to drop the 24V to 12V using resistor, too much heat and no speed regulation).
4) C7 Power Socket
5) 13x8mm Rocker Power Switch (Mine Aliexpress switches source is not available now but hope you can find them).
6) 12V 40x40x20mm Fan - used Sanyo Denki KDE1204PKV1 Maglev fan just because have them :) Use any you have. With fan grill.
7) Deans T-Plug Male Connector ("Dean") (obviously you need the female connector part too).
8) M2-M3 Screws, wirezzz... Alligator clips!

What should be done before assembly (you can get all info from uploaded photos):

1) 24V 6A PSU - desolder 24V 2-pin connector + right (looking at output PSU side) capacitor, resolder capacitor to the ex-connector place (and the wires going to StepDown to be soldered to the ex-capacitor place)
2) B3603 StepDown - desolder inter-board connectors, replace by wires (so that controller board, one with buttons, could be moved to the device front side apart of power board that will be located at the device's top). Desolder both power 2-pin connectors.
3) mini360 - fine as is but do not forget to tune it 12V-output. One more tip: mini360 is base on MP2307 chip that's high input voltage limit is 23V, not 24V so you should lower the voltage from 24A 6A PSU before - any diode or two will be OK. Or you can try setup with no diodes as the maximum limit is 26V or so. As for me, I decided not to risk (PSU to Serve, not to Fry).
4) As I forget to design M2 nut holders behind the C7 Socket so that you can screw when the case is closed, the C7 Socket needed to obtain melted-in nuts. Did it (check the photos).
5) Fine as is.
6) Cut wires, solder to the mini360 output, solder the mini360 input to 24V 6A output - that is.
7) How to fix firmly T-Plug Male inside the case? Easy! Make two half-holes on the both plug sides so that later you can fix it with 2 M3 screws. Check the photos.
8) Yes! Cut, flux, solder. Cut. Screw. Fun.

Dimensions: 135x63x51mm, weight 300g.

On 3D printed parts - you need to print Case Top+Bottom and the Buttons.
Mine was printed using all PLA, black and yellow. Tried to design minimising supports but the air holes and some screw holes need support so printed using auto-support generation feature.

Questions? Welcome!

author: Microdure

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Following on from my drag knife spindle attachement, I wanted a similar mechanism for attaching my laser (3.5W) to my spindle using a ring clamp. The spindle is an 80mm 2.2kW water cooled spindle and the ring attaches to the collar (narrower and black) at the bottom of the spindle.

I also needed a hood which serves two purposes. It helps direct the airflow from the cooling fan onto the cut/engrave point which helps clear any smoke and helps prevent burning along the edge of the cut. In truth it does not work nearly as good as a high power airjet right in at the cut but it's better than just the fan blowing over the cooling fins. The second purpose is to act as a shroud and helps stop laser light from bouncing all over the place. Let me be clear !!!THIS DOES NOT REMOVE THE NEED FOR THE CORRECT SAFETY GLASSES!!! when using lasers. The hood should just slide fit over the heatsink.

I also included some brackets to hold the driver board. Before printing you need to check your lasers dimensions to see that this will fit. Mine is 40mm x 40mm. The heatsink is 52mm from base to the start of the fan. Many of the commonly available laser diode modules of this power will have similar dimensions. The hole spacing on the rear plate should be 20mm x 40mm There may be a fifth hole on yours which you dont need to use.

The driver board bracket fits a board with a heat sink width of 47mm. You need to print two of these. This whole package allows me to quickly switch between using my laser and other tools and indeed the spindle itself very quickly. The ring locks in place with an M5 nut and bolt, Just hand tighten.

Lastly a great addition you can add to your laser setup is an airjet right in at the cut point. I've included a pic of mine which is simply a small metal tube bent and zip tied to the hood. Its attached via some silicone tubing to my airbrush compressor. Be sure to crush the end of the tube tight to increase the airflow speed out the end. To illustrate the difference I attach another pic showing the difference air-assist makes.

Hope you find some of this useful.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%
Designed in FreeCAD v0.16

This device should assemble fairly easily. Once prepared properly, that parts should fit together fairly easily. The ring is articulated to allow for easy use. Some parts may require some light sanding. The tolerances are pretty close to allow for parts to fit snugly.

Assembly

After cleaning parts of any build artifacts, fit the two ring halves at the rounded end. They should fit cleanly and can be rotated partially. Verify fit and mobility before installing ring pin. Once the ring halves fit properly and move freely, slightly sand the top of the post, rounding it slightly to allow it enter to small hole barely. Once the tip can be inserted in the hole, line up the three parts so the pin is aligned with the hole. Use a small hammer or other object to strike the pin, forcing it into the hole. Use caution keeping everything aligned. I was able to do it with a single quick strike! The ring should be able to be opened partially.
The rectangular "lock" slides over the posts of the closed ring. Light sanding may be required to make it easy to install and remove with minimal effort. The goal was to make it fit very snugly and is to help keep things in place while installing the main cage.
Finally, the cage can be inserted on the top of the post, using the key-like piece to lock it in place. The "key" will require some sanding to make it easy to install. A standard, thin zip-tie can be used in place of the key. I just wanted to provide everything you would need for a usable device.

WARNING: Take care to remove any supporting framework your printer may have created to support the cage. Leaving any sharp pieces behind could lead to a very uncomfortable fit! Use at your own risk! Use common sense. Make sure everything fit together and can come apart easily BEFORE use.

title: $5 filament spool and holder for Tiko 3D
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I finally got my Kickstarter Tiko 3D printer. The spool area on top is limited to 165mm spools. But it's not very fast and found leaving the included filament overnight had a tendency to break. So I thought Protoparadigm's $5 filament (200gm spools) were perfect for it. But the spool area on the Tiko is a bit large for the smaller spools and wanted make the filament as easy to feed as possible. I figured a spool on a stand.

After seeing a buddy's spool he used, I tried my hand at making my own spool. It was designed with two starts on the thread for faster alignment. I also wanted it to fit the print bed on the Tiko. Then made the base for the spool to spin on.

The spool glides well enough on the base as is, but designed it add three 623zz bearings in using M3x10 screws if need be.

CAUTION: These were not printed on a Tiko. Currently, my Tiko is not able to achieve reliable prints.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

10%

Notes:

2 shells/perimeters. 4 layers top and bottom.
Should feed smoothly enough, but for added glide, add three 623zz bearings using m3x10 screws.

comments.text: Can this be printed in a tiko? I have tried all day and the only thing I have been able to get to work is the base. Neither of the spools print.
comments.author: robsgarcia

comments.text: It was designed to be printed on the Tiko, but at least on my Tiko, it is currently not able to print anything reliably. I printed my set on another more reliable printer.
comments.author: robsgarcia

comments.text: Very Cool, thank you!  I especially like the fact that it screws together Can't wait to get some more filament to try it out!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Based heavily on the original thing (thanks Phredie), I flipped the object so that I could mount the flight controller on top, making the USB port accessible after assembly.

The inverted configuration means that the motors don't form the landing gear.

I also made it wider so that my batteries could fit under the flight controller.

These are the batteries I use: http://www.banggood.com/Syma-X5-15-X5C-3_7V-600MAH-Upgrade-Battery-Meal-p-941261.html. (Same size as the stock packs)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

123D Design was able to import the STP file from the original as an object. After importing, I push/pulled/coerced and separated the various parts. Flipped the object upside down so that the wider part of the duct printed on the bed.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

20%

Notes:

PLA BLANC

I found a working replacement for the heated bed thermistor. It reads 300k cold 18c
The first test was 3 , 100k thermistors in series the bed ran about 110c-122c while printing.
The second test was 4 , 100k thermistors in series the bed ran 75c-85c while printing.
The last test was to have 3, 100k thermistors in series and also a 100k trim pot in series.
While printing slowly adjusting it so that while printing to get a stable 88c to 95c while printing.
They are positioned under the center of the bed.
I wanted to do this because I was getting temps of 100c to 120c only in the center of the bed because the part being printed help keep in the heat only in the center.

100k thermistors http://a.co/aj6Jm3y

10A now with aluminum bed.

title: NEO Direct Drive Adapter for E3D v6 mod

description.text:
This is the adapter for the Direct Drive extruder by Hackbert merged with the axis mount of the Reprap Neo e3d v6 upgrade by Kakadu (already using my modified version).

I will soon try this out on my bowden extruder e3d v6 version. I think the Neo is so slow that the bowden extruder might not be needed and the extra weight by a DD extruder is tolerable. Let's see ...

This is still in progress. The first version wasn't watertight, please try the 'r2' version.

comments.text: Interessant! Ich bin gespannt ob das funktioniert! Ich habe vor ein neuer Schlitten für Dualextrusion zu machen somit wäre schon mal klar, wo der zweite Extruder hin kommt :) Ich hoffe deine Halterung funktioniert.
comments.author: Kakadu

comments.text: Leider hab ich das noch nicht montiert da mein NEO gerade eigentlich recht gut eingestellt ist, ich überlege aber, ob man da nicht auch was mit dem E3D Titan machen kann, der würde wenig Platz brauchen und könnte auf den Schlitten passen ohne oben herauszuschauen.
comments.author: Kakadu

comments.text: Bezüglich dem Titan Aufsatz ... ist da schon etwas passiert? Wäre spontan brennend daran interessiert :)
comments.author: Hoich

comments.text: Ich hab mittlerweile einen Titan-Extruder (naja, ist eher ein Nachbau, aber sieht genauso aus und ist gar nicht schlecht verarbeitet) und einen flachen NEMA17. Aber ich hab erst gestern den Umbau auf DirectDrive abgeschlossen (und wider Erwarten hat fast alles mit den Teilen im Modell hier und den Referenzen funktioniert). Was mir noch gefehlt hat war eine Bohrung für ein Push Fit im angepassten Compact Extruder und ein Gegenstück am Drucker um da den Bowden auch wieder festzumachen. Ersteres hab ich mit dem Bohrer gelöst ;) und zweiteres mit einem Stück Vinylbodenrest, das ich mit 2x M4x8 am Neo festgeschraubt hab und in dem dann in ca, 10cm Abstand ein Push Fit eingeschraubt ist. Damit hat das Filament jetzt einen schönen Weg zum Extruder. Achja, und gedruckt hab ich damit auch schon einmal - und er hat jetzt richtig Dampf - keine Unterextrusion mehr :) Ich muss nur noch ein paar Dinge nochmal drucken, dann mach in Update mit Bildern.
comments.author: extrudercat

author: jonsport1004

description.text:
I based this model on the TS filter drawer for Canon quick changer (http://www.teleskop-express.de/shop/product_info.php/info/p5748_Filter-Drawer-for-D-36mm-unmountes-filters---for-the-TS-Filter-Quick-Changer.html).

I found that there wasn't any drawer for 48mm unmounted filters, only with cell and those do not work with the low profile quick changer. So i create a new one!

The holes are 2.8mm in diameter, I use a M3 screw to create the thread and with "Nut Job" I design a 3mm long M3 screw which fits perfectly. However, with the test model I found that if you make the thread without care, the screw will not fit correctly. A possible solution could be making the M3 screw around 3.1mm in diameter.

M3 x3mm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2041728

EDIT: I minimize the heigh of the external cover to prevent it to hit with my flattener.

title: Geeko
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Ce petit gecko est parfait pour amuser les enfants, illustrer un exposé sur les reptiles ou encore décorer un Néo Terrarium (je crée régulièrement des items à assembler pour créer un Néo Terrarium, mi-imprimé mi-matériaux vivants) . Il est imprimable à la verticale ou à l'horizontale, avec support. Il a déjà été imprimé sur plusieurs machines, je recommande une impression de 9 cm minimum de longueur pour profiter des détails tels que la peau et les doigts.

Défense de reproduire à des fins commerciales, merci de ne pas modifier le fichier.
Imprimé par un follower de ma page Facebook Imprimé par Laurent de AL3D Concept

Rendu sur ZBrush

J'ai conçu ce petit Gecko à partir de ZSpheres pour former le corps (de la tête jusqu'à la queue) puis j'ai travaillé chaque patte séparément, pour ensuite les ajouter en subtools, ensuite j'ai travaillé les textures et matières à la mains, sans plaquage qui ajout de bruit, pour avoir un rendu naturel, il m'a fallut environ 7h de modélisation.

title: Prusa 2 front side panel clip for XXL Smart LCD Controller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BPV7myojRiC

I wanted to mount a raprapdiscount.com XXL Smart LCD Controller on my classic Prusa 2. This clip is available in DXF (for laser cutting) and STL (for 3D printing).

print v2a for the 63mm side of the board, and v2b for the 80mm side. should be a snug fit. I used 3mm thick material. YMMV.

outside dimensions should be ~98.9 mm * 75.9 mm.
I cut off the middle leg for the 80mm side of the board, and the bottom leg for the 63mm side of the board. Since I did this on my laser cutter it was easy to add one extra line.

Fusion 360

I used the STL of the metric frame-vertex.stl part from the Prusa 2 github page to measure the distance between each bar on the front of the Prusa 2. I laser cut one design, tested it, tweaked for clearances that I didn't anticipate, and on the second try everything was great. This is what you have here.

author: walfy07

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA to print this thing and it works great (the clip itself and the little latch have just the right amount of flexibility)

description.text:
This is a belt clip to hold the Playstation 4 VR cable.
I tried to create a slim but robust clip, that can be printed without support material. It mainly holds the connector unit with a strong base section designed around the cable outlet. It also grabs the unit with a little latch on its top edge to hold it in place while handling it.

The clip can be installed quite easy by inserting the cable into the base section gap and then slide-in the connector-unit until it ends up locked in place, under the small latch. The small latch is designed to bend a little to apply some pressure - it might be necessary to use a little screwdriver to lift the notch a bit in order to get it over the connector-units edge (I had to, but I guess this depends on how your printer is calibrated).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

It's important to print the thing the way it is oriented in the STL file (the clips strength depends on layer orientation).

I used PLA to print this thing and it works great (the clip itself and the little latch have just the right amount of flexibility)

comments.text:
Perfect fit and seems to be stronger than others models found since now.
Nice model !
comments.author: Glob30

comments.text:
Thanks for your feedback!
The strength of a part mainly depends on layer orientation relative to the applied forces.
Especially the perimeters provide fiber-like properties. Always try to make the forces pull on the filament fibers instead of the layer joins.

I designed this to keep the bed springs more up right so the hot bed will not shift and bed leveling more consistent. title: Zmotor Standoff For Integrated Vertex-Zmotor Mount

description.text: This is a standoff and coupler that solves the problem of really long 3mm bolts by rotating the motor so short screws can be used both for the motor and to hold the assembly down.

Assemble the couplers with nut and set screw.
Drop 4 14 mm screws into the bottom holes before mounting the motor with 8 mm screws. Press a coupler onto the top nut and rotate both z rods The same but so that tha side you are installing will expose the setscrew out one of the openings. Turn the motor shaft so tha the flat spot aligns with the set screw and push the motor-standoff assembly into the z-vertex, making sure that the motor shaft goes into the shaft hole in the coupler. Tighten the mount screws and the set screw and repeat for the other side.
This standoff is 45mm long, and may not work with other couplers. If folks want a longer standoff let me know. I have also released the Alibre source files.

title: MRap - Modular RepRap 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What is an MRap?

This is the first iteration of the MRap 3D Printer. It is based around an lightweight xy-gantry and z-bed system. Because of that high speeds and high precision without ringing or other artifacts can be achieved.
All parts can be ordered through a 3dhubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/service/141617

Parts List

  • 8x CornerBracket.stl
    • 24x M6x40mm Hex Bolt
    • 32x M4x10mm Hex Bolt
    • 32x 12mm Washer with 4/4.5mm Hole
    • 32x M4 T-Slot Nut (Cou can print some yourself!)
  • 4x ZRailBracket.stl
  • 8x BearingBlock.stl
  • 8x 300mm 20x20 Aluminium Extrusion
  • 6x 340mm 20x20 Aluminium Extrusion

... more to come...

Changelog

01/16/2017

  • Created CornerBracket for Frame Assembly
  • Created BearingBlock for XY Gantry System

01/17/2017

  • Created TBracket for Z Axis Assembly
  • Created Holders for AzteegX5Mini and ArduinoMega2560/Ramps

01/18/2017

  • Created XYSlider for XY Gantry System
  • Created Printhead
  • Created Holders for Azteeg X3 Pro, Azteeg X3, GT2560, MKS Base and MKS SBase
  • Created BushingAdapter to use 8/10/15 bronze bushings instead of igus/lm8uu bearings
  • Changed Bearing Bores to be more fault-tolerant

01/19/2017

  • Created Holders for Generation 6, Duet and Rumba

01/22/2017

  • Created Cable Clips for small zip ties that you can rotate in the extrusions
  • Modified Printhead and XYSlider to accept Bronze Bushings instead of Igus LM8UU replacement

01/23/2017

  • Created RailAngle that connects the Bed Frame to the MGN12 Rail
  • Changed Bushing Distance and Bushing Bore Size

02/08/2017

  • Creaded BearingBlockZ to attach a leadscrew to the frame

title: Key Holder - Low Profile Magnetic
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A low-profile key holder for stashing outside somewhere. My wife had our 2 year old lock her outside the house one evening when she stepped out to grab the mail while I was out of town, and had to wait 45 minutes while someone with a spare key came to unlock the door. Needless to say she put me to work to hide a key outside.

The lid is universal, and will work with any of the "boxes". Print the lid and any 1 of the 3 "boxes".

Included are 2 custom versions (Emtek and Kwikset) that can be used for those, or similar, styles. There is also an empty version that can be used for other styles, or anything you choose.

There are 4 holes for 4mmx2mm magnets.

STEP and Fusion 360 files are included if you'd like to customize them.

title: Alternate sliding sensor mount and hot end clamp

description.text:
I liked Grogo666's sliding Z clamp, however I needed more room to fit in my fan shroud. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2042039/#files So I modified the hot end clamp portion of Grogo666's thing to move the sensor to one side as far as I could. While I was at it I added a small tab to tie the heater and thermistor wires to and a larger mounting location for another cooling fan. I included the z clamp from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1837968 so you do not need to download it separately.

Only the M0101 Hotend_clamp-FRONT vr2 and new_Z_clamp are needed needed to work. If you want to use the fan shroud you will need all 3 pieces.

You will also need 3xM3 nuts, one M3x50 to slide in, one woodscrew or M3x10 with a nut.

Assembly should be pretty straight forward : screw one nut onto the M3x50 about 16mm from the head, put the nuts in, screw the M3x50 in the nuts (let 25mm up outside), put the clamp on proximity sensor (bottom up), rotate so that the M3x50 is front of reserved hole for its head, just shove the M3x50 in place, run the 3rd nut up to the bottom of the front clamp to keep the screw from lifting. Use the wood screw or the M3x10 to clamp the Z clamp tight to the sensor.

Sometimes it's not the dungeon, but how you get there....

This sign post is meant to compliment my modular roads system and is designed for any tabletop RPG (great for random encounters while your party caravans their way to the next destination) or wargame, or for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

The character model shown is from Wargames Foundry.

Enjoy!

description.text:
The Ready RepRap is a delta type 3D printer designed to be quickly assembled in a classroom with minimal tools using mostly low cost easily available parts. The design uses a minimal 3d-printed parts count.

The printer uses electrical metal tubing (EMT) for the linear motion rails, and commonly available electrical boxes to squarely mount the tubes between a wooden top and base.

The Ready RepRap is designed around an Arduino type microcontroller such as the Mega/RAMPS running open source firmware such as Marlin. The controller parts, stepper motors, hotend, and filament extruder are parts that will need to be ordered online.

The printer can be configured to print with either ABS or PLA type filaments, and has a cylindrical build volume measuring 10 inches in diameter and up to 12 inches tall.

The hardware scheme is very easy to scale up or down for different versions of this printer if you want to experiment on your own!
CCSS

What’s a RepRap?
For some background, the word RepRap is a shortening of the term “Replicating Rapid-Prototyper.” The RepRap project started as a British initiative to develop a 3D printer that can print most of its own components. The goal is to spark innovation and to produce this technology at low cost. The RepRap project is now made up of hundreds of collaborators world wide. Most of the work on various types of RepRaps, including the Ready RepRap, can be found on the website RepRap.org. This project was conceived as a way to make building a 3D printer more accessible to educators and students with beginning-level technical knowledge. This manual has been organized around a series of pictures showing each and every step of the process. Emphasis has been placed on the use of simple hand tools and the use of easy-to-find materials. There are a few special parts, like stepper motors and microcontrollers that will need to be ordered online. Building a working RepRap 3D printer can be a challenging project even for seasoned builders and engineers. Fortunately, you are not alone in the process! There are many online resources at RepRap.org and various help threads on the topics of everything related to making 3D printers. The best advice that I can offer is that you should expect this to take longer than you think, that it will not work right the first time, but that you will succeed if you do not give up. If you build this, you will learn how to do lots of other things in the process, and that’s the real reason for trying anything new. When you look at the list of items to collect & print, don’t panic. They’re organized into categories. Just take your time - it could take a month or more to get all of this stuff together. This project is best accomplished as a team of people with a mixture of different backgrounds and skills. It is part electronics, part programming, part shop, part scheduling, part online shopping, and part problem solving. Have fun!

The following is the fulltext instructions for creating the Ready RepRap. If you want the text with the accompanying pictures, download them from the GitHub page at the following link: https://github.com/dhartkop/ReadyRepRap Build Your Own Ready RepRap
by David Hartkop
published into CC BY-SA 4.0 2017 “Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn.”
-Benjamin Franklin “Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood.”
-Marie Curie “Tomorrow belongs to those who can hear it coming”
-David Bowie Table of Contents What is the Ready RepRap?

0.2 Overview of the project Preparation

2.4 Make the Universal Joint Rods
2.5 Make the heated print bed
2.6 Assemble the whole machine
2.7 Wire the whole machine
2.8 Get the software running 3D Printing
